text: Hi, this is Kate from MinuteEarth.

I know from personal experience that it can
take a ton of time, energy, and resources

to gather even a teensy bit of information
about wild animals.

But recently, technology has given wildlife
biologists new ways to study critters - like

using undersea microphones to monitor humpback
whales and satellites to study elephants - and

these methods can generate mountains of information
really rapidly.

Take the Snapshot Serengeti project, where
more than 200 automatic cameras across the

savannah have amassed millions of photos of
animals - predator and prey, day and night,

near and far, head-on and...whatever that
is.
That kind of bonanza is bananas!

But wildlife biologists have had trouble figuring
out how to actually deal with all that information.

I mean, when the Snapshot Serengeti scientists
go to actually use these images, they can’t

just plug them into a spreadsheet… they
need to know who’s doing what with who in
each photo - in other words, they need data.

And turning all those photos into data has
already taken more than 30,000 hours - that’s
like working 8 hours a day for 14 years.

If only there was sort of automatic system
that could do the job; one that can learn

that not only is this is a zebra, but so is
this, and this, well...used to be one.
Some sort of...artificial intelligence.

The scientists built a computer program that
essentially uses trial and error to learn

to identify dozens of species, count animals,
and categorize behaviors.

The AI turned out to be able to do this stuff
about as accurately as humans - and the photos

that took 14 years of human labor to classify
took the program just a single day.

Plus, the more opportunities these kinds of
algorithms have to practice, the better they

get, so the mountains of information that
were such a burden to researchers are actually
awesome for artificial intelligence.

And you know another place we can go to find
mountains and mountains of information?
The internet.

One AI-based program spends each night combing
through the 80 years of Youtube videos uploaded

that day, looking for videos of whale sharks,
like that awesome one someone saw on their
vacation.

The bot IDs each individual based on its unique
constellation of spots and records info about

the sighting - all while the researchers are
catching some zzz’s.

That’s a whale of a change from what it
has normally taken to study animals in the

wild, and AI just might free up researchers’
time and resources to connect the dots and

draw new conclusions about their subjects
- a task where artificial intelligence still

can’t beat the good old-fashioned human
kind.
This video was sponsored by the university of Minnesota
where students, faculty and staff across all fields of study are working to
solve the grand challenges facing society.
One of these challenges is assuring clean water and sustainable ecosystems
which includes making sure that we understand ecosystems well enough to
help them thrive into the future
Dr. Criag Packer, the director of the university's lion center helped establish
the Snapshot Serengeti Project to collect information about how animals interact with each other
and with the environment, so that we can better conserve species
and manage ecosystems around the world
Thanks, University of Minnesota!
